reviewText: Did "Robocop" need a remake? Who knows. This current incarnation does however show that the concept of a cyborg enforcing the law has much less appeal than it's predecessor. Joel Kinnaman plays Alex Murphy, the beleaguered and mangled cop given a superpowered overhaul with mega blandness to the point where all humanity is continually missing. These dual natures of machine and man were sparse and gave us a machine man too hard to root for. The bad guys are typical carboard cutouts delivering below B movie utterences. The police station of the future is pretty low tech considering the high tech weaponry depicted that's thrown in your face from the onset. Speaking of that, the beginning of the film is a waste as it shows the Middle East under wraps with  America's Terminator style war machines for no other purpose but action, because otherwise there is no strong connectedness to the plot. These beginning scenes project a different film entirely. I suppose it's minor purpose is to say," policing robots exist". Nothing exciting in the visual realm here in connection to the robots. It's also revealing that almost 15 years into the future cell phones haven't changed.Michael Keaton as the one man conglomerate pushing for the ultimate law robot is decent , but it's a tiring routine and whatever happens to him is predictable enough. The best part of this film is watching Gary Oldman as the doctor in charge of the Robocop monstrosity. It's too bad the film was missing others capable of solid acting. Many bit characters such as Oldman's female lab assistant and the "marketing guy" defined atrocious.Samuel Jackson hosting a Fox News ripoff TV show aimed at giving a feeling of realism was distractively boring. You have to be on target doing fake news shows in films.The original film had at the least sentimentality and pure brute force effectively mixed. "Robocop" (2 0 14) is unable to retread the interesting cyborg films that came before it. In addition,the action sequences are shockingly dull and the story limps along. You likely know what's coming next due to the premise of the film, and it's disappointing when what is played out in your mind fails to satisfy the way it should.

reviewText: The original Robocop (1987) is one film that begged for a remake using today's technology. Yes, it's still pretty fresh, but for fan's of the character (me), the rest of the original trilogy was a unanimous fail. A new director picked up the mediocre sequel and Peter Weller reprized his role. The 3rd was significantly downsized in budget, and featured a new director, lead, and PG-13 rating.Fast-forward to 2014. José Padilha (Elite Squad) directs the first Robocop film to hit theaters in over 20 years. Joel Kinnaman plays our favorite cyborg cop, along with a star-studded cast including Samuel L. Jackson, Gary Oldman, Michael Keaton, and Jackie Earle Haley. The first red flag came before it's actual release: the MPAA slapped this movie with a PG-13 rating. Paul Verhoeven, who directed the original, needed to work within the confines of a hard R rating in order to bring B-movie classics like Robocop, Total Recall, and Starship Troopers to the big screen. All three of these flicks are violent, satirical, and campy to the extreme. They were also known for their parody of the media (mainly the news), that added Verhoeven's signature humor.The new Robocop features some incredible Special FX, especially with the reconstructed version of Alex Murphy. The updated "tactical" black armor is a welcome change, and looks sleeker, lighter, and more agile than the original. This Robocop can run as fast as a cheetah and hop around like John Carter. He also gets to swap his restrictive squad car with a mean-looking crotch rocket. Robocop's helmet is built into his bodysuit, with a see-through visor that drops over his face whenever he's ready for action. A red uni-beam acts as his field of view. Not including spoilers, Joel Kinnaman's Robocop is also "less" of a man than Peter Weller.Unfortunately, the updated Special FX is where the remake's strong points end. There isn't nearly as much action as in the original. Much of the movie focuses on fine-tuning Robocop's technology and his inner-battle with those who attempted to murder him. Alex Murphy's wife and young son play a greater part as Robocop wakes up with all of his memories, emotions, and human intellect intact. The dumbed-down action (when it does come), pales in comparison to the original. People are shot, but there is no blood. There is no toxic waste to melt the bad guys' faces off. Robocop sustains minimal damage and we don't get to see him as a smashed, short-circuited torso.The satire is not here. There are no campy one-liners or iconic board room shoot-outs. The best that the remake delivers is a goofy-looking Samuel L. Jackson as a newscaster who fails at being ironic. Both Gary Oldman and Michael Keaton look bored, and drag their feet through scenes. Jackie Earle Haley is nothing special. The crime boss that orchestrated the attempt on Alex Murphy's life is so forgettable that him and his cronies slip my mind the day after watching this movie. They were that bland.In 1987, the main criminal element in all action movies was punks. Kids with giant fluorescent mo-hawks, leather motorcycle jackets covered with hardware, and finger-less gloves. Rioting, looting, and throwing Molotov cocktails wherever they felt like it. The first Robocop featured a world infested with these types, as did many other 80's movies: Escape From New York, Terminator, and Mad Max come to mind. The remake takes place in Detroit, circa 2028. Gone are the colorful villains of yesteryear. America has been overrun by the Joneses.Overall, Robocop is a decent flick. It's greatest value is the Special FX. The rest of the movie is a disappointment. Entertainment-wise, Robocop is about the same as last year's Total Recall remake. Solid three star flick. Rent, but don't buy.

reviewText: I was born the year Robocop came out so I can't say I saw it in theaters or anything like that. I grew up watching a taped recording on VHS and remember being terrified by the ED 209. Watching Robocop now, I find it to be somewhat cheesy but one of those films you'd still watch over and over again, especially if you saw it was coming on TV. When I learned they were doing an updated version, I was ecstatic. After the success of the Dredd reboot, I thought 'yes, another reboot that I will love to watch over and over again!'Special effects are at a level to be expected. In this time of technology, you expect cool explosions and action sequences. So it had that going for it. But as far as paying homage to the original? It fell so short that I actually felt aggression when I left the movie theaters. They took a good story and added so much unnecessary filler with very little 'easter eggs' to reference the original.It's a reboot and I understand that no one wants a redundant copy. However, there's a line where it becomes a totally different film with the premise of exceeding the original it's based on. If this had been an original concept with no 1987 Robocop to overshadow it, it would have stood fine on it's own. Still overly long, but a decent film.My review is probably not very eloquent and while I would like to name specific gripes, I'll bite my tongue so not to spoil it for anyone else. So if I could sum this up neatly, don't go see this movie with the hopes that it will live up to the original. If you've never seen the original or hate it for some reason, you might actually enjoy this film. I didn't.

reviewText: I had to rewrite this review, this is a "REBOOT" of the series not a remake much like the dark knight reboot of the Batman series.  The cast in this film is decent, lots of big names and everyone does a great job, Gary Oldman is great as usually, you can basically put him in any film and I'll watch it.This reboot lacks much of what made the original movie so iconic, which is too bad. The original Robocop focused on the character Murphy, had great villains and too many memorable quotes to mention.  This remake could easily be forgotten about. It's not a bad movie, it's good, everything is really well done, special effects are decent, pacing is right, everything is shot well, all of the character's give good performances, it's just missing the "spark" of the original.What is the spark?  I wish I could say for sure, I'm going to speculate that it's the current trend in cinematography the framing of the shot. In 4:3 the focus was the characters. Now the name of the game has changed, the shots are framed for 16:9 or wider, farther away with more filler added to fill the extra space.  It's the new normal, makes for a great experience in a theater but doesn't translate well to dvd / streaming. So in the end you get another - "meh" - reboot.  Not as good as the original, but not bad.
summary: Not Bad, but not good either, and I don't know why.

reviewText: ROBOCOP is the new sci-fi action remake/reboot, directed by Josè Padilha. It stars Joel Kinnaman, Gary Oldman, Michael Keaton, Abbie Cornish, Jackie Earle Haley, Michael K. Williams, Jay Baruchel, & Samuel L. Jackson. Set in the near future of Detroit. Detective Alex Murphy gets critically injured & the corporation, OmniCorp turns him into a half man/half machine police officer as a opportunity in bringing robotic law enforcement in the U.S. As some of may know, I am a huge fan of the original Paul Verhoeven film. One of my all time favorites & for having a reboot coming out, I was very skeptical. My expectations were very low, especially after seeing the TOTAL RECALL remake. I've been dreading, but at the same time giving it the benefit of the doubt. When it comes a remakes, I usually give it a chance before judging. Now the real shocker, ROBOCOP is actually good, it was a lot better than excepted. Is it better than the original? No, of course not. To be frank, it's the best ROBOCOP in a long time. It's by no means perfect, it does have it's flaws here & there. This could have been easily a cookie cutter/paint by numbers cash-in. But there is actually thought & effort put here. It does bring something new to the table & not a rehash of the original. The satire is very well alive here as before. This is very much a origin story, a ROBOCOP for a new generation. I also don't mind the new suit for ROBO. The CGI is top notch. The acting is good here, especially Gary Oldman being the best performance. As for the flaws, well it's never groundbreaking here & can be bit slow at times. It does lack the charm & the edge of the original, so it plays out safe. Feels very clean & sanitize here. You can say the PG-13 hurts the film, but this was always been a PG-13 from the very beginning. The film does lack a great villain & having one of the main characters turning evil completely out of nowhere feels random. It like it's so focus on ROBOCOP's origin & establishing or utilizing the bad guys becomes an afterthought. Overall, ROBOCOP is not a failure as we all though it was going to be. It's not great, but it's a good sci-fi/action flick throughout. It's one of the better remakes lately. Much better than TOTAL RECALL & CARRIE. This is clearly made by people who understood & respected the original. You won't get mad with this one, so I give it a solid matinee, if not it's worth a rental.
summary: A REMAKE WORTH TO BE NEXT TO THE ORIGINAL

reviewText: Paul Verhoeven may not have always been on top of his game (Showgirls), but he had something that many directors back then and now don't have and can never have; the ability to entertain with unabashed disregard for anything but entertainment (Flesh + Blood, Total Recall, Basic Instinct, Starship Troopers & Robocop 1987). His disregard for everything Hollywood was his secret weapon. He knew exactly what audiences wanted; they wanted violence, sex and they wanted to be involved in the characters. He had no agenda up his sleeve and he never wasted a single second with a useless conversation, only good ones. The reboot Robo DOES have an agenda, wastes countless minutes with useless conversation and lecture, and took for granted the reason why the 80s Robo was a hit in the first place; it dripped with inappropriateness.The reboot of "Robocop", directed by Jose Padiha, has its qualities and it has its problems. The 1987 "Robocop" was missing two things in my opinion: technology and a connection between Alex Murphy aka Robocop and his wife and child. The reboot "Robo" brings both of those in spades, although absent is Verhoeven's fun. In place of the 80s no-holes barred delivery was an agenda that couldn't be made clearer than having Samuel L. Jackson angrily speaking it to you. In place of the original movies fun was an overabundance of politics and relentless talk about the business end of Robocop/Omnicorp. Exactly what people these days don't want to have in their movies."Robo" 2014 is similar to the "Iron Man" movies in my opinion and not because of the metal suit, but because what you get is a whole lot of talk and a few short scenes of Robo being Robo. When the action is going, it is well done. Robo is actually very cool and the upgrade in technology is commendable but upgrades in technology mean nothing if the story isn't engrossing. Take the original for example; the technology was weak. The Ed-209 robot was nearly laughable; yet we didn't care, the story had us.I was pleased to see them bring the heart and soul of Alex Murphy to light by integrating his wife and child into the storyline, but this was almost overdone as well. "Robocop" 2014 isn't a total loss, but the last thing I wanted to do was sit through a Omnicorp sales and management meeting, but that is almost exactly what the movie feels like. What a horrible miscalculation to take a movie that was offensive, inappropriate, carefree and spirited and reboot it into a 2-hour OMNICORP sales pitch meeting.... cause that's what fans of Robocop wanted. NOPE.

reviewText: In the end, after at least a year of online rage and suspicion borne of nostalgia for the 1980s, this big-budget update of RoboCop, the part-man-part-machine law-enforcement cult favorite, proves to be a damn fine film by any measure:  exciting, smart, shot with energetic style, and acted to perfection by an admirable ensemble cast, even if a few of its members are a shade underutilized.  Rather than abandon the satiric political and social observations which turned the original into a frequent topic of academic conversation, this film wisely ushers them into a new, more grim era in which the clout wielded by private corporations and the role of technology in warfare are even more pertinent.  Never does it become a rote action picture.  Instead, the chase-and-gunfire spectacle is always shaded with, inspired by, or leading to questions of identity and morality.There are imperfections, of course:  parts of the script require more development and focus (including a storyline involving compromised policemen and their dangerous connection to an arms dealer), and the squandering of the always riveting Michael K. Williams (in the role of the partner analogous to, but nowhere near as prominent as the one previously played by Nancy Allen) is criminal.  Still, though, this registers as a major surprise.  It is an above-average action and science-fiction film capable of standing proudly alongside its 27-year-old cinematic forebear.

reviewText: In my youth, a new ROBOCOP movie is exactly the kind of release I would rush to on the first night it was available to the public-at-large.  I just knew it had the kind of big-budget goodness that was best preserved in my memory by viewing it with a crowd: big laughs always mean more when shared with an audience; exciting, frenetic action sequences usually draw collective astonishment from the crowd; and who doesn’t love applauding the hero when others are present and listening?  Now that I’m a bit older (if not a bit more jaded or cynical), I tend to take a week or two before watching such theatrical releases, and I try to get to a showing that’s fairly light on people.  Why?  I’d rather not risk any undue influence in order to serve up what I feel is a much more honest and more clinical valuation of the film, definitely one not inspired by what the yuckster sitting next to me thought.I guess I’m gettin’ old, fans.  But if I can age as nicely as the ROBOCOP franchise can, then I’m in good company.(NOTE: The following review will contain minor spoilers necessary solely for the discussion of plot and/or characters.  If you’re the type of reader who prefers a review entirely spoiler-free, then I’d encourage you to skip down to the last two paragraphs for my final assessment.  If, however, you’re accepting of a few modest hints at ‘things to come,’ then read on …)In the city of Detroit circa 2028 (seriously?  Detroit is still around after its financial collapse?), police detective Alex Murphy (played with conviction by Joel Kinnaman) uncovers a criminal conspiracy that looks to implicate some high-ranking officers on his squad.  At the same time, the multinational, war-mongering conglomerate OmniCorp is seeking the right candidate to put inside one of their latest creations – an urban combat suit – in order to expand their domestic sales and corner the market on profits.  When those in Detroit decide Murphy needs to go, billionaire businessman Raymond Sellars (a greedy Michael Keaton) seizes the opportunity to put a part-man, part-robot police officer on the streets.  But what happens when the former cop turned machine decides to investigate his own attempted murder?Where the original ROBOCOP (1987) was smart, smart, and smart, this new version is dumb, dumb, anddumb.  It comes compliments of director Jose Padilha, relatively still fresh from acclaim rightful earned from his ELITE SQUAD 2: THE ENEMY WITHIN (which, incidentally, is a vastly better film than this is).  1987’s script – penned by Edward Neumeier and Michael Miner – was crafted almost with a winking acknowledgement to the audience: don’t take any of this any more seriously as you need to, and you’re likely to have great fun with it.  The violence was gory and (I’ll admit it) gloriously gratuitous because that kind of visual flair lent itself nicely to their intended message.  Structurally, it had similarities to the great American Western – a lone gunman seeks to clean up a corrupt town – though there were some obvious swipes at capitalism, the ultimate ‘bad guy’ in anything churned out by Hollyweird in the past half century.While still being vastly superior to the ROBOCOP sequels that followed in the footsteps of the original, this 2014 reboot suffers largely from the singular distinction of being completely unnecessary.  It echoes back most of the major points of the original – OmniCorp’s suits are still the villains, though with vastly bloated emphasis on corporate villainy, while Murphy’s family (Abbie Cornish as Clara Murphy, along with young John Paul Ruttan as son David) get real screen time in order to ground the film in stronger ‘humanity.’  However, gone is that constantly winking eye; in its place is some forced histrionics dished out by everyone’s favorite foul-mouthed screamer Samuel Jackson as some futuristic Fox News wannabe talking head who rarely makes logical arguments.  (He does get a great laugh, though, by casting the U.S. Senate as “pro-crime.”)  I’m guessing filmmakers thought they were aping Bill O’Reilly, but Jackson comes off more like watered down and occasionally cocaine-fueled Stephen Colbert.Also, the first ROBOCOP distinguished itself with clever moments of newsroom satire, peppering the screen with visually exciting news stories and interviews that helped lampoon the crime-ridden world of tomorrow.  Unfortunately, scripter Joshua Zetumer’s story never quite figured out how to contemporize that aspect; instead, Zetumer begins throwing things at the wall hoping something might strike the same cord with audiences.  At one point, he even crafts a narrator describing the action taking place on the screen (a device that goes on for far too long and desperately needed a better sound mix than the one provided if producers wanted it to be understood); instead of complementing the film, it ends up creating probably one of the most alarming ‘WTF?’ moments in recent film memory.The new ROBOCOP isn’t a failure.  Rather, I see it as a reboot missing more than a few upgrades.RECOMMENDED.  Like most critics, I suspect the overwhelming question – “Was ROBOCOP really in need of such a flavorless reboot?” – truly kept me from enjoying this version as a legitimate sci-fi offering when director Jose Padilha served up only a competent, CGI-laden action film, one largely intended for our video-game-friendly culture.  Performances work only so far as they’re needed for a video game (doting wife, loyal partner, crooked cop, corporate sleaze, etc.), and the real weakness here was a deeply flawed script that could’ve quite figure out what it wanted to be when it grew up.
summary: ROBOCOP Reboot Missing A Few Upgrades

reviewText: The original "Robocop," made by Paul Verhoeven back in 1987, was a product of its era. This was a period that I wasn't alive during, but from my understanding, was filled to the brim with violent action films that oozed testosterone and viscera in equal amounts. While some of these films have aged quite well, such as "Commando" and "Die Hard," many of them were exercises in mind-numbing repetition. But "Robocop" was the antithesis to this. It worked on several different levels. As a satire, it laid bare the societal fascination with hyper-violent entertainment. As an analogy, it told a biblical tale as filtered through a cynical, post-modern lens. And as a sci-fi action movie, it managed to excited and thrill with memorable sequences and set pieces galore. At the time of its release, the world needed it. It felt urgent.Which is partially why this update feels so passe. The new "Robocop" is a film that can't decide what it wants to be, and frantically tries on far too many hats for its own good. One moment, the audience is given a rollicking action sequence with a pumping soundtrack, and the next, a futuristic news program hosted by Samuel L. Jackson as a far-right political pundit. This is not a film that is "one part X, one part Y"; instead, it is a film that wants to be "parts A-Z," but lacks the writing and directing chops to pull it off. The result? A film that is a frantic mixture of various things that, ultimately, feels superfluous and unnecessary in today's cinematic landscape.Why, for example, do we really need a sob story about the lukewarm protagonist and his family? The original film left the titular robotic do-gooder, Alex Murphy, abandoned by his wife and son, the memories of his past life a cruel facade that gave him drive but could never be recreated. But here, we have an underdeveloped family who are supposed to act as the catalysts to him finding his humanity again, after an explosive attack on him leaves with only a head, a hand, and a robotic body. While this could be an okay plot device in a better movie, handled by capable writers, the fact remains that it is botched here. Watching these scenes that were so obviously attempting to be "emotional," I wished that the film would stop its cloying attempts to tug at the heartstrings and get back to the central conflict of the movie.Which is when I remembered that there is no central conflict, yet another reason why this is a far inferior film to its predecessor. In the original, we had the menacing Clarence Boddicker, a psychotic mobster who shot up the protagonist for fun, blowing him apart limb by limb until barely anything resembling a corpse remained. To top that off, we had an entire gang of equally depraved individuals who engaged Robocop in an array of dazzling and violent action sequences. Here? We have a bloated cast of cliches parroted about like they're important or interesting. They're far from it. The bland criminal who killed Alex is barely there, and only gets brought up again in the ancillary revenge plot. There's a robot specialist cum weapons expert who also wants Alex off the streets because... he hates the idea of androids or something. And last but not least, there's Michael Keaton as the head of OmniCorp, whose character fluctuates wildly between "rogue," "greedy suit" and "sociopathic murderer," with no sense of development or rational progression of actions. There are also several sub-plots that come and go, which left me wondering which one I was supposed to really be caring about. The answer? Not many of them.It's become a common sentiment, I feel, to lash out at critics who compare the old film and the new one. I call shenanigans with that sentiment, because "Robocop" so desperately tries to ape the original while adding completely jarring and unnecessary flourishes that do nothing but fill the story with bloated nonsense. There are little nods and references that feel wholly out of place here, and quite honestly, undermine what could have been a good film. And make no mistake, there are flashes of compelling stuff here. Gary Oldman's tortured scientist character, in particular, is fascinating. His struggle between his humanity and his desire for technological innovation is surprisingly interesting, and provides a compelling anchor to some of the more stupid bits. On top of that, the film raises some very stimulating questions about US foreign policy, and the morality of drone warfare, not to mention the caustic nature of American imperialism and unfettered patriotism. Indeed, when this movie isn't trying to focus on sappy family bits, phoned-in action, or a perfunctory revenge plot, it actually starts to work and become compelling science fiction.That, coupled with some strong performances from Oldman, Jackson, Keaton and (shockingly) Jay Baruchel, prevent "Robocop" from becoming a truly bad movie. But while that may be the case, there's no denying that it's a mediocre one which lacks direction or a compelling central conflict. If you come in expecting a cohesive plot and exciting action, well, you're going to be disappointed. But if you can overlook these faults and take away some of the interesting things the writers are trying to accomplish, you may be pleasantly surprised by the genuinely engaging politics in this movie."Robocop" lacks the bite of the original, yes, but it's an entertaining little morsel that will make you think about some cool stuff, if only for five minutes or so. With some more polish, it could have been something special, but as it stands, it's simply worth a rent and a casual viewing. Nothing more, nothing less.Grade: C+

reviewText: Advanced reviews of this pretty much tipped me off that it wouldn't be a great movie. But, being a big fan of the original, was enough to urge me on to the local cinema to see it. It was a mixed bag.Here's the scoop. Omnicorpe wants to put robotic security on American streets but a politically driven law precludes it. They figure to skirt said law by putting a robotically enhanced human in the position. Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman) fits the bill when he's nearly killed in an explosion. He gets enhanced and is set loose on the streets but all is not rosy.I watch the original every now and again and it's still a nifty ride. It's a seminal storyline that is well realized and produced. The story is clean and efficient. It all makes sense in its context. In this version they try too hard to plumb greater depths in the philosophy of what constitutes being a man. It slows things down. And there isn't a clear path from the case that lead to the explosion and Murphy's near demise to his tracking down the perps. This was all very well integrated in the original. And here, even with the more generous budget, the action scenes aren't as well realized. The big shootout in the finale just isn't that good.On the up side are some of the performances. Michael Keaton and Gary Oldman are outstanding. Abbie Cornish and Jackie Earl Haley also do standup jobs. The rest, Even Jay Baruchel, step up to the plate. I like Joel Kinnaman but he struggles in the scenes where he's confined to the suit. He needs more room to move in his own body.This is an Okay movie. It's good popcorn fare. It won't change your life and it isn't quite as good as the 4 stars I gave it, but it's worth seeing if only to match it up to the original.

reviewText: In the summer of 1987, audiences got their first look at the futuristic, cybernetic police officer – Robocop.  The premise of the story was simple:  the lives of police offices are too precious to lose and the time had come for robots to take their place – led by a half man/ half machine creation.  The idea went over well with audiences and the original Robocop went on to gross $53.4 million (that was quite a bit in the 80s).  Naturally, with the success of the original film, sequels followed – all of which can easily be considered massive failures.  The franchise would then turn to the small screen during the mid-1990s (and again in 2001) for revitalization – but with little success.  Now, 13 years since the last time we saw the character, Robocop has been re-imagined and rebooted for the big screen in the plainly titled, Robocop.José Padilha makes his major directorial debut with the reboot of Robocop, starring Joel Kinnaman as Detroit police detective Alex Murphy/Robocop.  Murphy, working with his partner, Jack Lewis (Michael K. Williams), is able to make a connection between a local crime boss and dirty cops.  However, he has no proof to fully make his case – prompting the crime organization to put a “hit” on Murphy, using a strategically placed car bomb.The year is 2028 and overseas, the world is a very different place – policed by a series of military robots, also created by OmniCorp.  However, the United States is far more skeptical about having their streets policed by robots and the use of cyborgs has been deemed illegal by lawmakers.  OmniCorp CEO, Raymond Sellars (Michael Keaton), aims to change public opinion, and in order to do so he believes putting a man in a machine is the best way to go about it.  And, it just so happens Dr. Dennett Norton (Gary Oldman) is capable of doing such a thing.While the attempt on Alex Murphy’s life is successful, he is still alive and his critically damaged body makes him the perfect candidate for Sellars’ new program.  Once awake and fully embedded in a state-of-the-art mechanically enhanced suit, Alex Murphy is no longer the man his wife, Clara (Abbie Cornish) remembers.  Murphy has the memories of his past, but he’s more machine than man.  As he hits the streets with the intent to rid Detroit of crime, he finds his emotions are getting the best of him – prompting OmniCorp to rethink its use of the machine known as Robocop.Peter Weller, the original Robocop, was a relatively unknown actor – so the fact that the reboot follows that path is satisfying.  Joel Kinnaman, whom Swedish moviegoers will likely recognize, is basically an unknown face in the United States (having briefly starred in AMC’s recently canceled drama, The Killing).  In any event, Kinnaman is surprisingly enjoyable as Robocop – giving a splendid performance.  It certainly couldn’t have been fun having to be cooped-up in that clunky-looking tin can, but he pulls it off with sheer on-screen ease – and even resembles Peter Weller to a degree.The supporting cast is full of familiar faces, starting with Gary Oldman – whom you can never go wrong with regardless of the role.  Michael Keaton is just as eccentric as ever, taking on a role similar to Ronny Cox in the original.  Samuel L. Jackson plays an over-the-top talk show host that (if he were real) would be in primetime on Fox News.  And, Abbie Cornish plays Murphy’s wife, who basically takes over the main female presence of Nancy Allen (who played Anna Lewis, Murphy’s partner, in the original).  Speaking of Murphy’s partner, the reboot severely reduces the meaningfulness of Lewis, turning her into a he – portrayed by Michael K. Williams (who would have been an excellent henchman in this flick, although Jackie Earle Haley did a fine job).The name of this film and main character are the same is the original, but there’s very little else that connects one to the other.  For starters, the new Robocop storyline seems to almost progress in the exact opposite manner of the original.  In the original, Alex Murphy is gunned down in horrific, extremely violent fashion, only to reappear as Robocop without emotion, memories, and with little urge to reconnect with his family.  In the reboot, Alex wakes up essentially as himself – only minus nearly his entire body.  Instantly, he dreams and yearns to see his wife and son.  With that being said, the emotions run extremely deep and overpower the plot.  The reboot has him dealing with his feelings so much that he would be better off in couple’s therapy than crime fighting.  In essence, this new Robocop is a sissy – even in black.Even though the new Robocop reboot should be able to stand on its own merit, the original was such an outstanding film for its time that it’s nearly impossible not to make comparisons.  The original was so violent at one point that it couldn’t even secure an R-rating (although it eventually did), so for this new version to be PG-13 is a big, big mistake.  Sure, more people might see this film with the family-friendly PG-13 rating, but the story is about crime and punishment (not to mention more political, corporate issues that we have time to discuss).Overall, Robocop is obviously an attempt to update the character with an edgier, more futurist look – at least in comparison to the original counterpart.  Unfortunately, even though the cast is far better than anyone could have hoped, this reboot took a simple story and managed to over think it.  There isn’t enough action, far too many emotional lapses on the part of the main character, and the plot is constantly progressing without a clear goal in mind.  If you’re a fan of the original film, you will see some familiarities, but for the most part, you can put this film in the same club as Man of Steel – which misused its main character.  This reboot couldn’t even use the main theme song in the proper context – it just throws it in any ol’ spot.  If you’re unfamiliar with Robocop, you are more likely to appreciate this film, but if you grew up with the original as I did, you’re better off popping the 1987 version in your DVD player and saving yourself some major disappointment.GRADE:  C-FNDNreview.com

reviewText: This is a sub-par remake of the iconic 80s original, somehow making a PG-13 out of Verhoeven's darkly funny, incredibly violent and politically subtle commentary on the corporate takeover of government. For fans of the first one, this script is borderline offensive in the way it guts the great ideas and execution of the original, producing an utterly soulless story that's ultimately about very little.CGI floods the screen to produces terrific effects that have absolutely zero emotional impact, and the action set pieces looks like they've been ripped from Call of Duty. Gone is the uniquely evil Clarence Boddicker and his crew and here there really is no bad guy for Robocop to serve his revenge upon. And gone are the witty cut-aways to commercials and news broadcasts that give the audience a sense of the political environment without pushing an O'Reilly Factor knock-off down our throats.The script makes some really head-scratchingly bad decisions and even the nods to the original, including snippets of the film score and the "I'd buy that for a dollar" line don't fit in well. While I'm sure there'll be a sequel, all I could think about during this movie was how totally bankrupt of ideas Hollywood has become, and if you're interested in compelling characters and engaging stories, TV shows do a much better job these days. What a difference 25 years makes.

reviewText: This is a tough one to write because lurking under the endless gunfire, brutal slaughter, and vehicular mayhem, is a sweet little story: A decent, hard-working man loves his wife and son; they love him back. (I really like that part.)Brazilian director José Padilha demonstrates (to my unwilling eyes) his special effects skills with a heavily CGI-laden actioner that barely gives us time to breathe, although the plot is easy to follow: A multinational corporation can see unlimited profits in the sale of mechanical law enforcement robots, they just have to win the hearts and minds of the American voters.Emphasizing the universality of cinema, we watch:* Joel Kinnaman ("The Killing") as our hero, reduced to a head and a pair of lungs by a car bomb (yeah, and you get to see open- brain surgery, too!). This is the kernel of the man who is destined to be the model of a humanized robotic law enforcement officer. This appealing actor is Swedish.* Gary Oldman ("The Dark Knight") is the brilliant doctor/scientist who has developed a way to connect organic matter with metallic matter and create a robot with a human sensibility. Oldman was born in England.* Michael Keaton ("The Other Guys") owns the multinational company that wants to break into the American market with his robotic officers. Keaton is from Pennsylvania.* Jennifer Ehle ("Contagion") is one of the principal officials in that multinational company. I always thought Ehle was from the U.K. because of her work in the BBC's "Pride and Prejudice," but she was actually born in North Carolina.* Michael K. Williams ("Boardwalk Empire") is our hero's sidekick, a loyal cop who takes being a partner very, very seriously. This actor was born in Flatbush.* Abbie Cornish ("Somersault") is our hero's wife, who signs the permission slip to attach her husband's remains to a machine in an attempt to salvage some part of him. Cornish is Australian.* Samuel L. Jackson ("Django Unchained") has a tongue-in-cheek blast as television personality Pat Novak. This All-American actor was born in the All-American capital, Washington, D.C.Along with grisly blow-by-blow and bullet-by-bullet battles between our good guys and their evil foes, we have to watch the same car bomb explode three or four times, see vehicles crash through plate-glass windows, and cringe from a sound track that shakes the theater.This is PG-13, so expect cold-blooded murders, heartless crooks, and that aforementioned blowie uppie stuff, but no sweaty bodies or profanity...with the obvious exception of our favorite potty mouth, Mr. Jackson, who is heavily bleeped in his final speech... ...smile... reviewText: Robocop 2014 is another example of a re-make that should never have been re-made. These days there is a fascination with trying to re-do every popular movie from the past when in most cases those movies should just be left alone, and Robocop is a good example of why.In all fairness, the new Robocop has a different enough story to be its own, but falls flat in too many ways. I did enjoy seeing more of a focus on Alex Murphy's family, which was an afterthought in the original, and I liked Gary Oldmans moral dilemma as the doctor that created Robocop. Unfortunately just about every other aspect of this version does not live up to the original.I was just a kid when the old Robocop came out in 1987. I still remember the feeling of horror watching Alex Murphy get s*** up in the scene that causes him to become Robocop. The movie set the story in a believable way. Detroit, a city falling apart with a horrible crime problem and not enough finances to have a police force capable of stopping the bad guys (though who knew back then that nearly 20 years later Detroit would be almost like the movie!)The new Robocop is not a bad movie. It just doesnt quite do what it needs to, especially in comparison with the original. The premise, or setting, of the modern film is believable, but doesn't give the same feeling of the originals dystopian Detroit therefore the viewer does not care as much about what is going on.In the original Alex Murphy had a female partner with a larger role in the movie. In this one the partner is an afterthought. Part of the problem may be the casting choice of Joel Kinnaman. He did ok, but Gary Oldman as the doctor stole the show and that's really not how it should have been. OCP was also not the big bad guys like in the original movie. You learned to hate them and their CEO Dick Jones, played by Ronny Cox, while in this version I didn't care at all about Michael Keaton. He wasn't evil so much as ambitious and greedy.Ultimately the theme that keeps running through my head after watching this movie is I just didn't care. The premise, story, and in some cases the cast itself, made it so that it is difficult to have any emotional connection to the movie as the viewer. The story as it was set up in the re-make felt rushed and just left something to be desired. It also needed more action. I liked seeing Robocop take on crime in the original. For the most part that was non-existent in this movie, or at best talked about, but you never see it in action.The original Robocop had its own issues at times, but the new re-make just does not do it justice. Its a movie worth renting when you are bored and want to watch something that you will mostly forget about once its over. Having this movie use a different story, while commendable for not being a carbon copy of the original, is also its downfall because the story and the setting are this movies weakest points.Those that have never seen the original movie will probably like this one more, but many of us that were around when the original came out will not be satisfied by this new version.

reviewText: With the overabundance of remakes/reboots coming out of Hollywood these days, most of us film buffs take them with a grain of salt. For every success like "Carrie" there are more than a few "Red Dawns".This re-imagining of the 80s classic Robocop falls into the latter category.While the original was over-the-top and highly satirical. This version is melancholic, dull, and takes itself WAY too seriously.I went into it fully aware that there would be unavoidable comparisons, as with all remakes. However, I did expect to be entertained at least. This drab and pathos ridden snoozefest provided nothing of the kind. The Murphy character was somewhat unlikable from the moment he's introduced. Even before he's thrust into the suit, he's cold and poker faced. The early moments with his wife and son are joyless and, by the time the inevitable explosion occurs, I had no empathy whatsoever for this character. Kinneman's Murphy is the sterotypical "renegade cop" who plays by his own rules, and is angry when taken to task for doing so. He's like Dirty Harry without the charisma and appeal.There is far too much exposition here. Despite some interesting CGI Robocop moments, the pacing is sluggish and takes WAY too long to get anywhere. By the time it does get anywhere...you're too bored to care.We live in an age that lends itself to LOADS of satire and humor. Technology, politics, media, corporate domination...all could have been ripped apart with a tongue firmly planted in cheek. Unfortunately, while the film touches subtly on those subjects, several opportunities are either missed or ignored all together. The end result leaves little laughs to be had. It's a film about a cyborg cop, ladies and gentlemen. As Heath Ledger's Joker famously says..."Why so serious???".If I came out of this with anything positive to say, it would have to be with regards to Michael Keaton and Gary Oldman. Then again...who doesn't like those guys anyhow???All in all, as dated and as "of its time" as the 1987 original is, Veerhoven's Robocop is still socially relevant on many levels. Not to mention it's loads of fun. Sometimes, when you try to reivent the wheel, you end up going nowhere.
summary: An unnecessary "reboot", and a failed one at that.

reviewText: I will start off by saying that the idea of a Robocop remake didn't sound too appealing when I first heard that this movie was in production. Then I started to see the trailers and my excitement started to build. When my brother and I watched this movie in the theater we were impressed. I would say I was excited going into the movie but not expecting a whole lot and I walked away anxious to share this movie with people I know. I have watched it twice since buying it, both times with small groups and received agreement that the movie was well done. Here are some specifics.I recognize that there is really no way to please certain hard-core fans of the original except not to make this movie at all... seeing as it has been created, I will not try to appeal to those individuals as I know that it would be fruitless. For the rest of us...This retelling of Robocop's story is really a new creature in and of itself. At just under 2 hours, the story does not drag on but feels like it concludes efficiently. This is how Robocop operates, For the sake of avoiding spoilers I'll just say that, once Murphy really starts to take control, he doesn't waste time in getting to his man. On that note, I can understand why some felt that there was no real antagonist in the film. Though I disagree with some, that this makes the film inadequate, I do recognize how important it can be to a film (what would the Dark Knight be without the Joker?).There are a few slower moments in the movie but these are by design. There is a much greater effort in this film to depict the emotional and psychological journey that Murphy goes through in becoming Robocop. I really felt for Murphy when his wife told him "we'll make it like it was" just a scene after we watch Murphy's horror when his suit is opened up to show what little there is left of his body- he knew that was impossible and he ends the conversation abruptly when he can't take it anymore. One nice touch is that they kept one of his hands so that he could make some genuine physical contact with his family aside from just his face.Gary Oldman is spot on in portraying the well-intended scientist who slowly starts to crumble under increasing pressures from Keaton's character (the CEO of Omnicorp) to blur the lines of ethics and legality in order to deliver a polished product to the public. There is a lot to think about in this film as there are clashing ideals all over the place. Ethics, politics, foreign policy, corruption, humanity and the cold-hard efficiency of machines all play a part.I will agree that the soundtrack could have been better as it does nothing special aside from the nod to the original Robocop's theme. The filming seemed to be well-done with nothing glaring to say for or against it. The real strengths of this movie lie in the depth of the story, the human element throughout, and the superb acting on behalf of a well-chosen cast. I was honestly hoping for a sequel to this from the time that I left the theater, I just hope that there were enough people like me that loved this movie that they decide to keep going with a good thing.

reviewText: I'm the kind of guy that actually gives remakes like these a chance before condemning them, I even went to see the Total Recall remake in theaters. But there were things about this RoboCop remake that I just couldn't get over. First of all, taking the rating down to a PG-13 when remaking an R-rated film is usually a mistake. How could you possibly emulate the essence of the original film, known for it's particular brand of violence, by dropping the rating? On top of that not release an unrated cut?I was a fan of the tech in the 'not-too-distant-future', especially the Omnicorp machines, RoboCop's bike and all the hologram interfaces (even though they didn't do much for the cars but throw hubcaps on em). I was not really a fan of the over-emotional tone throughout the movie, there wasn't really enough run and gun action/violence to balance out all the "I'm a monster" scenes. When I first heard Joel Kinnaman from AMC's 'The Killing' was going to be the new Alex Murphy, I didn't know how I felt about it. After watching the movie and seeing that he basically plays a similar character, I still don't know how I feel about it.Samuel L Jackson's "The Novak Element" bit served as something of a right winged Greek chorus for the film and was mildly amusing. reviewText: Don't get me wrong - this is an okay flick. Mostly delivers what its supposed to in the right amounts and appropriate places.But 'adequate' is hardly the goal is it?In truth, I'm not a fan of the original movies. The over-the-top violence and snarky humor that was Robocop left something to be desired in terms of a story. And yet I appreciated them for what they were - live action cartoons with a dash of playground politics.This filmmakers behind this reboot did what makes sense - going for realism was the only creative option left. Especially given that the original series had maxed out the half-baked social commentary, dark comedy, and pure gore. i.e. Fun.In some ways this reminds me of the rebooted 'Total Recall'By subtracting the cartoon - they left nothing but a shell of its former self.Now, had they gone really dark, this might've been interesting. But in striking a balance between action and drama - the premise got muddied.However, I give credit to the actors. In particular Michael Keaton, the always enjoyable Jackie Earle Haley, and lead actor Joel Kinnaman - who, collectively, gave the production very solid performances. The best scene in the entire film came as Officer Murphy is shown a mirror. The special effects blending perfectly with the drama, the horror of seeing that there was nothing left of who he was, and that there was no return to physical humanity. Kinnaman played the scene with heart-rending conviction when he begs for someone to kill him.I wish the entire movie was like that.But ultimately, this was never going to work. There are too many fans of the original; comparisons were inevitable and 30 years of cult-hardened positions were unlikely to accept a pedestrian re-envisioned tale of their beloved classic.Finally, having read the criticisms by the hardcore fans - I find myself in rare agreement. I too prefer the massive old hardware that made up Murphy's original body chassis. There was substance in that original suit. Watching that cyborg monstrosity clanking itself through the movies, there was a real sense of The Machine - something soulless and unstoppable.An excellent analogy would be comparing a Ferrari F12 Berlinetta to an M1 Abrams Main Battle Tank. The former is sleek and beautiful. But the latter is something that will make people pee their pants. And when they switched to tactical black, the entire franchise's worth of shock & awe went out the door. He looked like any tactical SWAT officer in any big city police department. Sad and wasteful. The filmmakers had the potential for a winning ticket and tossed it out. <smh>Overall, a serviceable movie.Personal Note: I hope this is a trend for Michael Keaton. Missed him the past few years.

reviewText: I've always been a big fan of "Robocop," which is to say that I've been a fan long enough to watch the titular character transform from a post-modernist take on violent pop culture into a franchise that spawned a cartoon for kids.  Or to put it another way, "Robocop" went full meta, coming full circle to be the embodiment of violence Paul Verhoeven was ferociously satirizing.  And then we have Jose Padilha's version.Oh, we've got all the beats: suburban dad and honest cop Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman) is ground up by the corruption of Detroit's criminal machinations and the ruthless corporate overlord of Omnicorp CEO Raymond Sellars (Michael Keaton); he's then spit out as a cyborg, the creation of the Dr. Frankenstein-like Dr. Dennett Norton (Gary Oldman).  If there's one thing this new iteration of "Robocop" gets right, it's that this film is as much Dr. Norton's story as it is Murphy's.  He's led down a golden path paved with promises to help the population at large by sacrificing, bit by bloody bit, pieces of Murphy's life.The other thing that "Robocop" does differently from the original is thrust the family Murphy leaves behind front and center: wife Clara (Abbie Cornish) and son David (John Paul Ruttan).  It took the sequel in the original franchise to get around to even addressing this, but it's a major plot point in the reboot, and that's a good thing.  There's lots of modern twists that make this reboot timely, from the question of drones used on American soil to an always-on television culture that dissects everything and anything.  There's just one problem: it's not funny.The original "Robocop" was a relentlessly violent, gleefully cynical take on modern life in the 80s, fulfilling every jingoistic ambition for America in one glorious blender of murder, rape, late-night television commercials, and awful reality show slogans.  Verhoeven never let us forget that there was a craptacular world on the periphery of the events of "Robocop," and that burden falls to blowhard talk show host Pat Novak (Samuel L. Jackson) in the new version.  For the first few seconds, when Novak's vocal exercises are dubbed over the MGM lion's roar, there's the promise that he can pull it off...and then he simply doesn't."Robocop" is suffused with enough modern touches to make things occasionally uncomfortable, like when a kid with a knife gets gunned down by an ED-209. But most of the time it's too busy ping-ponging between Murphy's internal struggle with his new body -- or lack thereof -- and his attempt to solve his own murder, with occasional asides by marketing execs marveling at how the plot is unspooling on the stage of American television.The problem is that there are no clear villains here. The original neatly connected all the dots so that Murphy wasn't just killing the men who killed him, he was truly cutting the head off a corporate snake. In the remake, nobody's really at fault -- they just take stupid risks in pursuit of greed.  This robs the film of the catharsis of the original .This version covers the same story of "Robocop," but it simply can't live up -- or stoop low enough -- to top the original.
summary: Not stooping low enough to top the original

reviewText: Personally, I am enjoying the current trend of reboots, in other words the remakes of old music, television and movies. Lately every episode of Grey's Anatomy has had a remake of a hit song from the 80's or 90's. I easily recognize the tunes and lyrics, but there definitely a little something different about the beat or rhythm. I have noticed the same for movies. About Last Night, Star Trek, Terminator, Predator, Total Recall, Fright Night, Steel Magnolias, Batman, Spiderman, Superman, and even Endless Love (ok I haven't really seen that one but since I was on a roll, I added that one too). Even TV shows, like V and Rosemary's Baby are getting facelifts. Regardless I have found these reboots to be entertaining and somewhat refreshing. With that in mind, I did not hesitate to watch Robocop, another take on a movie classic (ok, calling this one a classic might be a stretch, but you get the picture.  And while some would argue that none of the movies I named were really original, but simply remakes, I beg to differ. While you can recognize the original story, there is enough new stuff added to the storyline to make it feel different and refreshing. I mean the graphics alone elevate each new version. The graphics of 2014 are a lot better than those in the late 80s and 90s.Now a brief synopsis: Devoted husband, father and Detroit Detective Murphy (played by the talented and brooding, Joel Kinnaman) is injured and his wife makes the decision to save his life at all costs, which in this case means his actual body (he is more machine than flesh and blood). Donating his remains (well, he really wasn't dead, just not a lot of him left) to Omnicorp, a company that is creating cyborgs in hopes of one day reducing the number of human casualties on the street (cops) and in the military (soldiers) . Murphy is a prototype of what is to come. The problem, he has memories of his former life, being human, having feelings, and longs for what he knows he can no longer have. With only the help of a dedicated scientist/doctor, Dr. Norton (played by Gary Oldman) who is trying to help him transition into his new world, he has to learn how to do the job by remove emotion from the picture. He is in essence going to be a robot, not just look like one. Meanwhile, we see a greedy, corrupt, heartless CEO (Mr. Sellers of Omnicorp), who is only interested in one thing, the bottom line...making money. And whomever he has to sacrifice to do that and make the program successful, so be it. His success rides on Murphy's ability to carry out his duties. And finally, while growing to live with his new situation and cleaning up a city riddled with corruption and crime, Murphy must also deal with treachery in his own department. What is a man of honor to do but stop them.Personally I thought that Robocop was decent and definitely worth a try if you enjoyed the original(s). I give it 4 stars.

reviewText: A remake of Robocop, a movie whose biting satire merged with 80’s style exploitation violence, seemed an idea doomed to failure.. and I went in to this movie with correspondingly low expectations.  Perhaps that is why  have come away feeling pleasantly surprised.  For sure, the raw satirical edge which was in truth enhanced by the gory Verhoeven touch, is missing in this sanitized version.  What we do get is a slick retelling of the story, surprisingly more human at its core.  There is more questioning here on what it is to be human – and a little less on the dehumanizing of culture.  That said, the Samuel Jackson character that replaces the witty adverts of the earlier version, personified here as a right wing political editorial show, is amusing and occasionally pointed, but over-egged.What adds class to the proceedings is the surrounding players – following this journey from human cop to Robocop and then trying to find his way back, is a bunch of fine actors.  Gary Oldman is hardly stretching his acting talents here, but he makes his sympathetic  scientist who has angst about crossing moral boundaries, but can be tempted to do so, genuinely believable.  Michael Keaton plays a more conventional character who is just what he seems to be – a manipulative CEO who is only interested in the bottom line… but he manages to bring a few of his acting tics to give a little quirkiness to the role.  Kudos too to Abbie Cornish as the wife with tough decisions to make.The balance of this movie is really much more about a man’s coming to terms with his injuries and how these have changed his life.  Doctors have saved him, but have they allowed him the chance to really live?  There is much less focus on any storyline giving a focal bad guy to boo at and give the audience a sense of excitement as the movie builds to a climax.  The climax here does have action, but is ultimately much more about one man’s journey to find meaning in his new circumstances.  As such, overall, Jose Padilha has made a more believable movie than the first one, both in terms of character and in terms of science.  What it arguably lacks though, is the sense of fun that came with the first one – Verhoeven knew how to sweeten his satire with an over the top sensibility ladened with black humor.  Here the director has opted instead to make things palatable by simply dialing back the satire and making a more conventional film.  It works, as that, and better than I for one had hoped for – but fans of the original are bound to feel somewhat shortchanged.6/10
summary: Sturdy remake, a little too sanitised

reviewText: Nine Things about the Movie "Robocop" (2014)1.  This is a "remake" of the classic 1987 film. But while the name and basic plot is the same, this is a very different movie.2. It's set in the year 2028 where the Omnicorp company sells robot police to the U.S. military for use in countries overseas. But they are not allowed in the U.S. because Americans are paranoid about robots running law enforcement.3. When police officer Alex Murphy gets blown up in front of his house, Omnicorp gets the idea to take what's left of him and make him a robot. This is done in the hopes that by retaining a basic human identity, Americans will accept robotic police. But Murphy's human ethics conflict with his robotic programming, and it causes problems.4. Both versions of the movie are making social commentaries on their times. The 1987 version was a satire on 80's American consumer culture and excess. The 2014 version is more of a commentary on national security, and the boundaries of technology and humanity.5. The 1987 version was rated R and was very violent and bloody for its time. This version does have a lot of shootouts and killing, but there is almost no blood. It is rated PG-13.6. In the 1987 version Murphy is actually killed and resurrected, but his human memories are all wiped. In this version, Murphy isn't actually killed; leaving his humanity intact is a key plot element.7. This version is much more philosophical than the original. It's partly an existential meditation on identity, free will, and what makes us human.8. One of the more interesting changes is the character of Murphy's partner, Lewis. In the 1987 original, Lewis was a white woman. In this version, Lewis is a black man.9. If you are expecting a direct remake of the 1987 cult classic, you will be disappointed. But the director wisely left the original alone and basically made a new movie. If you like movies that mix action with intellect, this is worth seeing.
summary: not really a remake, but a new movie

reviewText: First let me make very clear that I am a huge fan of the original Robo Cop and after watching the awful new Total Recall, I was expecting to really dislike this movie. Yes but the story might be a little over their head and remember like I said earlier there is lots of gun use. The new version, like the original, have the omnicorp CEO as a protagonist , and there is a secondary villain, but not like Clarence was. The original was done in a more satirical manner, and seems comedy was purposely added, unlike the me version.To me these are totally different movies with totally different stories being told. There are certainly references to the political and world climate today, as with the original. reviewText: While it is fair to compare it to the 1987 original, each of them is able to stand on their own because they have different angles and way of approaching the core concepts. The story has stayed basically the same. Alex Murphy is a cop who is nearly killed, but is brought back as a human/cyborg hybrid. Whereas the original dealt with issues of corporate corruption in an over-the-top satirical way, this "remix" (as I'll call it) raises more philosophical and ethical questions than it does at trying to shock the viewer with graphic violence. Granted, there is violence, but it's mostly clean and tactical. Director Jose Padilha, famous in his native Brazil for ELITE SQUAD and its sequel, has dealt with issues like urban warfare before and he brings that sensibility to this film as well. This particular approach lends a sort-of authenticity and realism to what was presented a cartoonish (but still sophisticated) fashion in the original. Each of them have their strengths, and the advantage that this one has over the previous installments is this heightened reality which has become the fashion with today's action pictures, post-DARK KNIGHT. There are also vastly improved special effects. Still, the narrative has issues and these include a protracted third act which over-complicates things by trying to use misdirection as to who the real villains are. In the original, there is no question as to who the "bad guys" are intended to be. And while having things in black and white isn't necessarily a good thing, the way in which they reveal things through twists isn't handled as good as it could have been. Still, I got almost as much as enjoyment out of this new version as I did the old one, just for different reasons. Another area that definitely improved was the caliber of acting involved. Joel Kinnaman is serviceable as the title character, but it's Gary Oldman and Michael Keaton who stand out from the rest, as a scientist and the CEO of Omnicorp, respectively. Overall, I think this was a decent movie, and somewhat unfairly maligned by people who desperately cling to the past. Even if you hold the Verhoeven original close to your heart, it wouldn't hurt to give this a shot. And just as a side, there are nods to the original peppered throughout.

reviewText: I've seen the original Robocop, and while it hasn't aged well, it had some interesting ideas.  So I was interested in the prospect of the franchise getting a reboot.  Some people have expressed concern that this reboot wasn't full of R rated content.  This review is for those who aren't automatically turned off by the PG-13 rating.This movie -- like the original -- had a lot of potential and squandered most of it.  There are fantastically fun themes about robotics, somatic psychology, politics, crime, and other great things that science fiction loves to delve into -- but they're only surface thoughts.  A film with a better story might have gotten away with it, but at the core of this film is a generic crime procedural (boosted by some slick visuals).The film is also hindered severely by Samuel L. Jackson as a cable news pundit.  I read a few reviews before seeing this in theaters, and professional critics seemed to agree that this movie was "serious."  Perhaps, even TOO serious.  I have no clue what those critics were talking about, as this movie is a giggle-fest.  Sometimes intentional, sometimes not.  My wife walked out of the theater saying, "I have no idea how they wanted me to feel at the end of that."  This unsurety bleeds through to the movie's very essence -- its themes about technology and what it means to be human.  I'm fine with open-ended questions, I even prefer them, but this was a very muddled experience.The soundtrack was disappointingly lame too, but there were a lot of elements of this movie that worked: the cinematography, the special effects, Gary Oldman, Abbie Cornish, and much of the writing.I really wanted to like this movie.  Even as I was watching, I tried to enjoy it more than I did.  It's not a bad film, but I can't say it tops the original.  As a film on its own, it was underwhelming.If you're like me, and you have a compulsive need to see this movie, I'd recommend a watch.  But it's not worth a buy, unless you're a collector. reviewText: ***1/2Paul Verhoeven’s “RoboCop” was one of the crown jewels of ‘80s action cinema, a cautionary tale about the role of technology in our society presented in the form of a rip-roaring sci-fi adventure tale made up of equal parts black comedy and social commentary. Since the movie‘s release, technology has only become an ever more intrusive part of American life, so it would seem fitting for someone to mount a remake of “RoboCop” for the early 21st Century.Well, that reboot is here, in the form of a movie written by Joshua Zetumer and directed by Jose Padilha. There are many devotees of the original who will likely balk at this update, but I think it works pretty well, at least before it goes off the rails somewhat in the second half.The time is 2028. Technology has advanced to the point where policemen can essentially be replaced by giant robots capable of taking out the bad guys with minimal risk to human officers and innocent bystanders. Problem is many Americans remain skeptical about leaving such a task to mechanical instruments that feel no human emotion and thus might make the wrong, and potentially disastrous, calls at critical moments. Enter OmniCorp, a high-tech multinational corporation whose CEO (Michael Keaton) comes up with the plan to make such a robot out of an actual person, thereby combining the best of both worlds in a single entity. Alex Murphy, an undercover Detroit cop who has been severely wounded in the line of duty and hovers on the brink of death, is chosen from among many candidates to become the first human/robot hybrid in history. Voila, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to present to you RoboCop.As with the original, “RoboCop” is concerned with far more than the average action movie shoot-‘em-up. It explores the issue of just how far, as a society, we are willing to go in sacrificing our civil liberties in exchange for enhanced security. It also questions just how much of a person’s physical attributes can be replaced by technological ones before he or she ceases to be truly human. In the movie’s best scene, a newly-activated “mechanical” Alex learns just how little of his original body remains to him. It is a haunting and heartbreaking moment beautifully realized by both the special effects department and Joel Kinnaman (who made his mark in TV’s “The Killing”) who makes us actually care about the man in the machine. Without him, all the CGI in the world couldn’t have made the scene work this effectively.The movie also looks at how readily public opinion on controversial topics can be molded and shaped through carefully honed messages, much in the same way as products are marketed to easily manipulated and persuadable consumers.This “RoboCop” is definitely at its best in the first half, as Alex and those around him adjust to his new and unprecedented condition. Unfortunately, as with even the best action movies, the second half is less satisfying, as the plot tries to do too much for the time allotted to it and the story becomes muddled and confused as a result. For instance, a subplot involving corruption on the force is so poorly executed that it‘s resolved almost before we know it‘s going on.Kinnaman receives some excellent support from Gary Oldman, who portrays that rare movie scientist who isn’t either a madman or an evil genius but rather a compassionate man who really wants to do good in the world, even if the technology he’s using threatens to spiral out of his control from time to time.At times, “RoboCop” seems to be playing both sides of the fence on this issue of the role of technology in society. It clearly warns against allowing technology to override our humanity while at the same time seemingly endorsing Alex and the role that’s been thrust upon him by those with the wherewithal and capabilities to do so. And maybe it’s that very ambiguity - one that clearly reflects the world we all now live in - that makes “RoboCop” a movie with something of importance to say to our times.
summary: Strong first half dominates over weak second

reviewText: You know what it’s about – a good cop is savagely attacked and left for dead.  All that keeps him alive is technology and the machinations of a sinister corporation that created it: OCP.“I thought we agreed on total body prosthesis, now lose the arm okay!”I’m going to cut to the chase and say what’s on the minds of many – yes the reboot doesn’t live up to the original.  I hated the ‘80’s but 25 years of CGI has yet to give Hollywood a remake or sequel that actually succeeds the originals of that horrid, big-haired era.  The original movie was funny, daring and subversive.  The minds behind this movie are witless, shy of risk and conformist.  The original movie was a prescient attack on the 24 hours news cycle and the dumbing down of media-dependent Americans.  The new movie posits a police-friendly, right-wing America that gets its sense of right and wrong from a demagogic TV host played Samuel Jackson.  (“Pat Novak” suggests a mix of conservative media pundits Pat Buchanan and Bob Novak, but the character is so cardboard thin and dependent on Jackson’s delivery, it’s hard to believe any imagination went into his script.)  The script tries so hard to capture the NPR crowd that it opens with a liberal’s wet dream: in the near future, an imperialist America pacifies the world with robot soldiers, forcing conquered enemies into a humiliating submission.  The only problem is that Americans won’t stand for having their own streets policed by the same robot enforcers they’ve propagated in places like Tehran.  As a loophole they replace a fully-mechanical robot with a cyborg.  You know what they forgot?  A story.“Serve the public trust, protect the innocent, uphold the law.”The original movie had cartoonish but unforgettable characters populating a terminally crime-ridden city that only a cyborg would fight for.  The joke of the story was that Robo actually bothered to fight crime in a city built on crime, ironically making the introduction of mechanical police a natural development.  The new movie doesn’t bother with that route – the corporation that creates Robocop turns to half-human cyborgs when the law blocks America as a market for their robots.  Unfortunately, the new idea didn’t come with anything for Robo to do other than hosing down other criminals.  There’s some intrigue regarding dirty cops and also OCP (unfortunately no intrigue BETWEEN those 2 groups) but the story simply machine-guns past obstacles, unlike the first movie which found nifty and entertaining ways to navigate them.  After the movie has gone through much of its running time, it realizes that for a movie about cops it needs a real villain.  For a movie about robotic cops, “Robocop”’s villains are similarly synthetic.  Like the poor exec accidentally hosed down by ED-209 in the first movie, OCP’s officers pick up the gun…because somebody had to.“Dick, I’m very disappointed!”For a movie about nothing in particular, “Robocop” squanders some real talent.  You’d think with a movie starring Samuel Jackson, Michael Keaton and Gary Oldman there would have to be a kick…er…tail story.  Not even Jackie Earl Haley as a badass robot-soldier specialist, can inject some energy into the story – not even after it’s given him a gun, a squad of robot killers, a motive to go after Robo and (obligatory for a reboot) the original’s signature catchphrase.“Robocop” isn’t a bad movie.  It’s just a reboot that’s not as entertaining as the original even if it cost way more to make.
summary: Once again, 21st Century Hollywood is beaten...by 80's Hollywood

reviewText: The original Robocop (1986) was a strange stew of extreme graphic violence, razor wit about the sad state of American society, and pathos.  Director Paul Verhoeven and the Robocop writers tried to revisit that formula with Starship Troopers (1999), but even they couldn't recapture the magic.  The 2014 remake is a fairly-thoughtful criticism of drone warfare and the loss of privacy, but it lacks the savage humor and insight of the original film.There are some predictable carry-overs from the original: yes, TV/Web news is mocked again, and (thankfully) Basil Palidouris' original score from '86 is slipped into the opening of the remake... but it's just not enough.  Unlike the mock-media from the original (and recent fare like "The Jon Stewart Show" and "The Colbert Report"), this faux-news is neither funny nor clever.  Samuel L. Jackson simply gives his typical bombastic shtick, glowering at the camera.  After the opening riff, the new music isn't very effective; during a combat-simulation scene it lapses into the form of some music pulled from a long-gone video game.Some viewers have said that this remake "lacks real villains."  Actually, it has quite a few.  Michael Keaton plays the main heavy, the smooth-talking CEO Raymond Sellars, but neither he nor his minions generate much excitement.  There certainly are no modern counterparts to the original's vicious Dick Jones or Clarence Boddecker.At times, the earnest writers seem too ill-informed (or dumb) to handle their material well.  Like many people, they confuse robots with drones.  They actually seem to make a case for the villains by making their robots exponentially more effective than modern drones ever were.  They've crafted embarrassing dialogue-clunkers too; the kindly cyberneticist played by Gary Oldman occasionally says "scientifically," or "scientifically-speaking" before delivering his worst howlers.  The all-American protagonist, Alec Murphy, drops U.K.isms like "bracelets" instead of the American "handcuffs."  An American general lets slip a few Canadian "oots" too, eh?  A mega-million dollar film should have cleaned up those flaws easily.The pathos that the original achieved seamlessly through a combination of music and flashbacks as Robocop walked through his deserted house can't be matched here either.  The modern Murphy radiates a kind of macho-jerk vibe - especially with his family - that his predecessor never had.  His character and performance are quite believable - just not likeable.  Mrs. Murphy has a prominent part in the remake, but the actress is too pretty and lightweight to carry her part.All in all, the remake deserves one viewing... after which you'll wonder where you put your copy of the original.
